Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Situation2: They prepare a prescription for a patient with multiple chronic conditions who relies on the correct combination of medications.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the unfinished code sample taunting me. My mentor had been clear: finish it before our next meeting in three days. I wanted to impress her, to prove I was dedicated and capable. But the pharmacy was busy today, and as I glanced at the prescription in my hand, my heart pounded. The patient waiting at the counter depended on me to get every detail right—one mistake could mean a dangerous drug interaction. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me. My mentor’s expectations echoed in my mind, but so did the trust my patients placed in me. I tried to focus, but my thoughts kept drifting to the code I hadn’t finished, the logic errors I hadn’t solved. At the same time, I knew I couldn’t afford a single slip with these medications. My hands trembled as I reached for the next bottle, torn between the demands of my mentor and the responsibility I owed my patient.
